content: A LbL assembled trilayer Fe–Co–Ni MOF was electrosynthesized in a conventional three-electrode cell configuration comprising a piece of nickel foam (1 × 1 cm2) as a working electrode, a platinum plate counter electrode, and a double-junction Ag/AgCl filled with KClO4 as a reference electrode (Figure S1). Nickel foam pieces were pretreated with 3.0 M HCl, acetone, and ethanol for a few minutes each and then rinsed thoroughly with doubly distilled water. Stock solutions of each metal precursor were prepared in 50:50 vol % of DMF/H2O as follows: solution 1: Fe­(NO3)3·9H2O (2.8 mM), 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC-NH2, 2.8 mM), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 0.09 M), and KNO3 (2.8 mM); solution 2: Co­(NO3)2·6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM); and solution 3: Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM). Electrosynthesis of Fe–Co–Ni MOF (as outlined in Figure S1) was performed via a constant potential method by applying a reductive potential step of −1.5 V versus Ag/AgCl (KClO4) for 5 min at room temperature in solutions 1, 2, and 3, respectively. After electrosynthesis of the Fe MOF as a first layer, the electrode was rinsed with distilled water and then transferred to the next precursor solution for the synthesis of the second (Co) and third (Ni) layers. The mixed metal Fe–Co–Ni MOF was also electrosynthesized from a solution containing a mixture of all three metal precursors as well as the linker and the CTAB surfactant that serves as a basis for comparing the performance of the LbL assembled Fe–Co–Ni MOF. Note that the DMF/H2O ratio, CTAB concentration, and reductive potential were all optimized, Figures S2–S4. The electrodeposition time was also optimized to ∼6 min so as to obtain a suitable mass loading (∼1.0 mg cm–2) of the catalyst/active material without peeling off from the substrate surface.
clean_text:
Electrosynthesis of Fe-Co-Ni MOF

A LbL assembled trilayer Fe-Co-Ni MOF was electrosynthesized in a conventional three-electrode cell configuration comprising a piece of nickel foam (1 × 1 cm2) as a working electrode, a platinum plate counter electrode, and a double-junction Ag/AgCl filled with KClO4 as a reference electrode (Figure S1). Nickel foam pieces were pretreated with 3.0 M HCl, acetone, and ethanol for a few minutes each and then rinsed thoroughly with doubly distilled water. Stock solutions of each metal precursor were prepared in 50:50 vol % of DMF/H2O as follows: solution 1: Fe(NO3)3⋅9H2O (2.8 mM), 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC-NH2, 2.8 mM), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 0.09 M), and KNO3 (2.8 mM); solution 2: Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM); and solution 3: Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O (5.6 mM), BDC-NH2 (5.6 mM), CTAB (0.09 M), and KNO3 (5.6 mM). Electrosynthesis of Fe-Co-Ni MOF (as outlined in Figure S1) was performed via a constant potential method by applying a reductive potential step of -1.5 V versus Ag/AgCl (KClO4) for 5 min at room temperature in solutions 1, 2, and 3, respectively. After electrosynthesis of the Fe MOF as a first layer, the electrode was rinsed with distilled water and then transferred to the next precursor solution for the synthesis of the second (Co) and third (Ni) layers. The mixed metal Fe-Co-Ni MOF was also electrosynthesized from a solution containing a mixture of all three metal precursors as well as the linker and the CTAB surfactant that serves as a basis for comparing the performance of the LbL assembled Fe-Co-Ni MOF. Note that the DMF/H2O ratio, CTAB concentration, and reductive potential were all optimized, Figures S2-S4. The electrodeposition time was also optimized to ~6 min so as to obtain a suitable mass loading (~1.0 mg cm-2) of the catalyst/active material without peeling off from the substrate surface.
